segments.text: During the First World War.
Right.
And when the SATC was in operation there.

And sneered at those of us who were not in uniform, like me, who was an instructor, and I was told that I had to remain, that the college had to carry on, classes had to be held as they had been held before the war.
And I took it as long as I could, so I went back into service.
So you gave up your teaching job there for the time being.
Yeah.
Where did you go into service?
Louisville, Kentucky.
I went into the artillery.
And I stayed there.
Would have gotten my own commission, but during the last month of my time in Louisville, Kentucky, war ended and said they wanted to know why I stayed here.
So I packed up and came home and attended Texas.
I mean, came back, took my old job.
You were starting to say you had an interesting experience during the war.
In other words, in 1917, when all of them were going in, I was going to go in too, you see, with the rest of them.
Dr. Bezell said no, that I'd stay.
So I stayed.
And of course, I was... And they drafted me.
And I went in then as a draftee from this area.
And...
Of course, as a draftee, I became first sergeant of the company there.
I was there from September until December when orders came that I was to be discharged.
I was discharged for being erroneously inducted into military service.
Then after I'd been there that period of time, I went back to A&M again, to my old job.
And that's when SATC was sneering and spitting at these boys, and I decided I couldn't take it, so I went to the field artillery.
F-A-C-O-T-S, Field Artillery.
That was the initials of this company.
Then of course I was there
Until about the time I was to receive my commission, when I just checked out.
That ended my war service.
So I have two discharges, one on them and one just a discharge.
Because you were erroneously inducted.
Erroneously inducted in the military service.
I imagine there are not very many people who have two discharges from World War I.
No.
I actually had three.
I had one in the National Guard.
I joined the National Guard after I come back.
You say you joined after you came back?
From World War I. Uh-huh.
How long were you in the National Guard then?
I don't know just how long.
About a couple of years, I imagine, then we disbanded.
And you were in the National Guard then in Bryan and College Station?
Right.
Uh-huh.
At one point, I believe you were named as a distinguished student from Texas A&M.
Yeah.
Was that a fairly high honor for you to receive?
It was.
That was in recognition of what, your contribution to teaching?
Well, my contribution as a student.
Now, you didn't have reference to this honorary degree I got.
No, this was the Association of Former Students at Texas A&M named you a distinguished alumnus.
It was, well, I've forgotten exactly how many years ago.
See, I was president of that association, you know, and it was the largest organization on the campus.
Now, you were president of the Alumni Association?
I was president of the Student Organization.
Scientific Agricultural Association.
I think that's what it was called.
You get that from the annual, but that's what it was called.
What I had reference to was something which the Former Students Association at Texas A&M awarded you a certificate as a distinguished alumnus.
This would have been while you were teaching here at Tech.
No.
I thought you had received one of those.
No.
No, I haven't.
I received an honorary doctorate degree.
That was from whom?
Texas A&M.
Texas A&M?
Yeah.
When did you receive that?
In 56 or 57, somewhere.
Of course, that's the highest degree I could receive from A&M.
of which I'm, of course, very proud.
Up to that time, I was called a degree I.N.
I got a bachelor's here, a master's today at Missouri, and then I got this honorary doctorate from Texas A&M.
Okay.
